human.title: FUTURE-AI: Guiding Principles and Consensus Recommendations for Trustworthy Artificial Intelligence in Future Medical Imaging
human.generation:
The recent advancements in artificial intelligence (AI) combined with the
extensive amount of data generated by today's clinical systems, has led to the
development of imaging AI solutions across the whole value chain of medical
imaging, including image reconstruction, medical image segmentation,
image-based diagnosis and treatment planning. Notwithstanding the successes and
future potential of AI in medical imaging, many stakeholders are concerned of
the potential risks and ethical implications of imaging AI solutions, which are
perceived as complex, opaque, and difficult to comprehend, utilise, and trust
in critical clinical applications. Despite these concerns and risks, there are
currently no concrete guidelines and best practices for guiding future AI
developments in medical imaging towards increased trust, safety and adoption.
To bridge this gap, this paper introduces a careful selection of guiding
principles drawn from the accumulated experiences, consensus, and best
practices from five large European projects on AI in Health Imaging. These
guiding principles are named FUTURE-AI and its building blocks consist of (i)
Fairness, (ii) Universality, (iii) Traceability, (iv) Usability, (v) Robustness
and (vi) Explainability. In a step-by-step approach, these guidelines are
further translated into a framework of concrete recommendations for specifying,
developing, evaluating, and deploying technically, clinically and ethically
trustworthy AI solutions into clinical practice.

human.title: EdgeFlow: Achieving Practical Interactive Segmentation with Edge-Guided Flow
human.generation:
High-quality training data play a key role in image segmentation tasks.
Usually, pixel-level annotations are expensive, laborious and time-consuming
for the large volume of training data. To reduce labelling cost and improve
segmentation quality, interactive segmentation methods have been proposed,
which provide the result with just a few clicks. However, their performance
does not meet the requirements of practical segmentation tasks in terms of
speed and accuracy. In this work, we propose EdgeFlow, a novel architecture
that fully utilizes interactive information of user clicks with edge-guided
flow. Our method achieves state-of-the-art performance without any
post-processing or iterative optimization scheme. Comprehensive experiments on
benchmarks also demonstrate the superiority of our method. In addition, with
the proposed method, we develop an efficient interactive segmentation tool for
practical data annotation tasks. The source code and tool is avaliable at
https://github.com/PaddlePaddle/PaddleSeg.

human.title: Semi-supervised Contrastive Learning for Label-efficient Medical Image Segmentation
human.generation:
The success of deep learning methods in medical image segmentation tasks
heavily depends on a large amount of labeled data to supervise the training. On
the other hand, the annotation of biomedical images requires domain knowledge
and can be laborious. Recently, contrastive learning has demonstrated great
potential in learning latent representation of images even without any label.
Existing works have explored its application to biomedical image segmentation
where only a small portion of data is labeled, through a pre-training phase
based on self-supervised contrastive learning without using any labels followed
by a supervised fine-tuning phase on the labeled portion of data only. In this
paper, we establish that by including the limited label in formation in the
pre-training phase, it is possible to boost the performance of contrastive
learning. We propose a supervised local contrastive loss that leverages limited
pixel-wise annotation to force pixels with the same label to gather around in
the embedding space. Such loss needs pixel-wise computation which can be
expensive for large images, and we further propose two strategies, downsampling
and block division, to address the issue. We evaluate our methods on two public
biomedical image datasets of different modalities. With different amounts of
labeled data, our methods consistently outperform the state-of-the-art
contrast-based methods and other semi-supervised learning techniques.

llama-chat.title: FUTURE-AI: Guiding Principles and Consensus Recommendations for Trustworthy Artificial Intelligence in Future Medical Imaging
llama-chat.prompt: Write the abstract for the academic paper titled "FUTURE-AI: Guiding Principles and Consensus Recommendations for Trustworthy Artificial Intelligence in Future Medical Imaging".
llama-chat.generation:

The paper is the result of a collaborative effort between academia, industry, and regulatory bodies to address the ethical, social, and technical challenges associated with the use of AI in medical imaging.

The authors argue that as AI becomes increasingly integrated into medical imaging, it is essential to ensure that these systems are not only technically proficient but also trustworthy, transparent, and ethical. They propose a set of guiding principles that emphasize the importance of patient-centered design, transparency, accountability, and inclusivity in the development and deployment of AI in medical imaging.

The paper also presents consensus recommendations for the development, validation, and deployment of AI in medical imaging, including the need for diverse and representative datasets, robust testing and validation methodologies, and ongoing monitoring and evaluation of AI performance. The authors emphasize the importance of addressing the ethical and social implications of AI in medical imaging, such as ensuring that AI systems do not perpetuate or exacerbate existing health disparities.

The authors also highlight the need for a collaborative approach to the development and regulation of AI in medical imaging, involving stakeholders from academia, industry, regulatory bodies, and patient advocacy groups. They propose a framework for regulatory oversight that balances innovation with patient safety and privacy, and emphasize the importance of ongoing education and training for healthcare professionals to ensure that they are equipped to use AI effectively and responsibly.

Overall, the paper provides a comprehensive roadmap for the development and deployment of trustworthy AI in medical imaging, and highlights the need for a multidisciplinary approach to address

Their aim is to assist stakeholders during development, implementation, and usage of AI in medical imaging; this involves emphasizing patient-centered design, open dialogue among authorities, maintaining Data privacy , security measures, and transparent algorithmic processes . Furthermore, they encourage continuous evaluation & refinement, aligning AI utilization with human values like accountability and non-discrimination while promoting collaboration between academia, industry, healthcare organizations, and regulatory bodies for successful incorporation of trustworthy AI into clinical practice.  
By providing these expert suggestions supported by their extensive review outlining the present knowledge landscape and emerging challenges related to AI use in medical imaging.

llama-chat.title: EdgeFlow: Achieving Practical Interactive Segmentation with Edge-Guided Flow
llama-chat.prompt: Write the abstract for the academic paper titled "EdgeFlow: Achieving Practical Interactive Segmentation with Edge-Guided Flow".
llama-chat.generation:
In this paper, we present EdgeFlow, a novel approach to interactive segmentation that leverages the concept of edge-guided flow to achieve practical and efficient segmentation of images. Interactive segmentation is a fundamental task in computer vision that involves allowing a user to interact with an image to indicate the regions of interest. However, existing methods for interactive segmentation are often limited by their reliance on iterative user input, which can be time-consuming and may not accurately capture the user's intended segmentation.

EdgeFlow addresses these limitations by introducing a new approach that combines the efficiency of edge-guided segmentation with the practicality of interactive segmentation. Our approach uses a novel edge-guided flow algorithm that propagates user input along the edges of an image, allowing for fast and accurate segmentation of complex images. We demonstrate the effectiveness of EdgeFlow through extensive experiments on several benchmark datasets, showing that it outperforms state-of-the-art interactive segmentation methods in terms of both efficiency and accuracy.

In addition, we explore the versatility of EdgeFlow by applying it to a variety of applications, including object segmentation, medical image segmentation, and video segmentation. Our results show that EdgeFlow can handle a wide range of scenarios, from simple object segmentation to complex medical image segmentation, and can accurately segment objects in real-time.

Overall, EdgeFlow represents a significant advancement in the field of interactive segmentation, providing a practical and efficient approach that can be used in a variety of applications. Its ability to accurately segment images with minimal user input makes it an ideal tool for a wide range of users, from researchers to practitioners.

mpt.title: EdgeFlow: Achieving Practical Interactive Segmentation with Edge-Guided Flow
mpt.prompt: The following is the full text of the abstract for a research paper titled "EdgeFlow: Achieving Practical Interactive Segmentation with Edge-Guided Flow" from arxiv.org:
mpt.generation:
> We present EdgeFlow, a novel interactive segmentation framework that achieves practical interactive segmentation with edge-guided flow. EdgeFlow is a two-stage framework that first generates a coarse segmentation result with a fast edge-guided flow network, and then refines the result with a slow but accurate segmentation network. The edge-guided flow network is trained to generate a coarse segmentation result that is close to the ground truth segmentation, and the segmentation network is trained to refine the coarse segmentation result. The edge-guided flow network is trained with a novel edge-guided flow loss that encourages the network to generate a coarse segmentation result that is close to the ground truth segmentation. The segmentation network is trained with a novel segmentation loss that encourages the network to refine the coarse segmentation result generated by the edge-guided flow network. We evaluate EdgeFlow on the Interactive Segmentation Benchmark (ISB) and show that EdgeFlow achieves state-of-the-art performance on the ISB.

## EdgeFlow: Achieving Practical Interactive Segmentation with Edge-Guided Flow

### Abstract

We present EdgeFlow, a novel interactive segmentation framework that achieves practical interactive segmentation with edge-guided flow. EdgeFlow is a two-stage framework that first generates a coarse segmentation result with a fast edge-guided flow network, and then refines the result with a slow but accurate segmentation network. The edge-guided flow network is trained to generate a coarse segmentation result that is close to the ground truth segmentation, and the segmentation network is trained to refine the coarse segmentation result. The edge-guided flow network is trained with a novel edge-guided flow loss that encourages the network to generate a coarse segmentation result that is close to the ground truth segmentation. The segmentation network is trained with a novel segmentation loss that encourages the network to refine the coarse segmentation result generated by the edge-guided flow network. We evaluate EdgeFlow on the Interactive Segmentation Benchmark (ISB) and show that EdgeFlow achieves state-of-the-art performance on the ISB.

gpt2.title: FUTURE-AI: Guiding Principles and Consensus Recommendations for Trustworthy Artificial Intelligence in Future Medical Imaging
gpt2.prompt: The following is the full text of the abstract for a research paper titled "FUTURE-AI: Guiding Principles and Consensus Recommendations for Trustworthy Artificial Intelligence in Future Medical Imaging" from arxiv.org:
gpt2.generation:
[Abstract] At present, future medical imaging is increasingly being used to diagnose patients with cancer or other life-threatening problems without a physician's input (1⇓⇓–4). In fact, this level of patient monitoring has emerged as an urgent need and a cost effective alternative to a conventional surgical strategy of operationally treating disease when clinical findings warrant it (5, 6). However, current techniques are relatively costly compared to human surgeons who still perform a significant portion of total imaging-related revenue (7). Consequently, healthcare systems must now prioritize not just what images should be captured but how they ought to be collected and organized (8). To date, many experts have agreed that large volumes do require to be recorded (9) for certain types of health issues such as cardiac infarction detection in which information is relevant beyond simply allowing doctors to detect atrial fibrillation [6]. These guidelines also dictate use of standardized storage methods for storing medically useful clinical information on large-scale data centers (10), although others would like to see greater transparency about which institutions hold the most medical data, thereby enabling citizens to decide whether privacy is important when making healthcare decisions using mass data (11). Despite these differences, no consensus approach exists regarding the best way forward with respect to both capturing mass imaging images and maintaining appropriate access, quality and security while recording them on centralized data sources. This raises the question: Should we seek solutions which maximize efficiency while minimizing the amount stored or rely only on technologies for storing information?

We propose the following guiding principles for designing trustworthy artificial intelligence in the field of medical imaging and apply them to several challenges currently facing contemporary diagnostic machine learning that include: identifying common diseases in high volume samples; detecting noncontroversial features in large quantities at low accuracy through pattern recognition or image classification based on prior knowledge, like heart rate, pupil size; locating and cataloguing images to obtain relevant contextual context that may contribute to treatment recommendations and identify potential anomalies; performing post-processing routines such as pre and/or post activation (activation steps) and noise correction, as well as creating customized visualization programs by automatically modifying predefined templates in order to better understand what is represented in these files; and providing continuous feedback as to how the algorithms are interpreting the medical data and helping healthcare physicians make decisions regarding management

mistral.title: FUTURE-AI: Guiding Principles and Consensus Recommendations for Trustworthy Artificial Intelligence in Future Medical Imaging
mistral.prompt: The following is the full text of the abstract for a research paper titled "FUTURE-AI: Guiding Principles and Consensus Recommendations for Trustworthy Artificial Intelligence in Future Medical Imaging" from arxiv.org:
mistral.generation:
> Artificial intelligence (AI) is increasingly being used in medical imaging to improve diagnostic accuracy, reduce workload, and improve patient care. However, the use of AI in medical imaging raises ethical, legal, and social issues that must be addressed to ensure the safe and effective use of AI in healthcare.
>
> In this paper, we present the results of a consensus-building process that involved a multidisciplinary group of experts in AI, ethics, law, and medicine. The goal of the process was to develop a set of guiding principles and consensus recommendations for trustworthy AI in future medical imaging.
>
> The process involved a series of workshops and online discussions, during which the experts identified key ethical, legal, and social issues related to the use of AI in medical imaging. The experts then developed a set of guiding principles and consensus recommendations for trustworthy AI in future medical imaging.
>
> The guiding principles and consensus recommendations cover a wide range of issues, including transparency, accountability, fairness, privacy, and security. The principles and recommendations are intended to provide a framework for the development and use of AI in medical imaging, and to ensure that AI is used in a way that is safe, effective, and ethical.
>
> The results of the consensus-building process are presented in this paper, along with a discussion of the implications for the development and use of AI in medical imaging. The paper also highlights the need for continued research and collaboration to ensure that AI is used in a way that is safe, effective, and ethical.

The paper was published on arxiv.org on March 20, 2023.

mistral.title: FUTURE-AI: Guiding Principles and Consensus Recommendations for Trustworthy Artificial Intelligence in Future Medical Imaging
mistral.prompt: The following is the full text of the abstract for a research paper titled "FUTURE-AI: Guiding Principles and Consensus Recommendations for Trustworthy Artificial Intelligence in Future Medical Imaging" from arxiv.org:
mistral.generation: Artificial intelligence (AI), and particularly machine learning, has become increasingly prevalent within healthcare as diagnostic support technology known as artificial intelligence medical systems, with applications spanning multiple areas including radiology and pathology imaging data interpretation but also genomics to facilitate precision medicine efforts. In response to this rapid innovation dynamic, we seek to help ensure that AI within all contexts of health care are trustworthy through the lens of human-machine collaboration. Toward these ends, experts representing a diversity of disciplines engaged across government agencies, academic institutions, industry leaders, and patient advocacy group representatives gathered at an international workshop entitled FUTURE-AI. A major goal was to elucidate how best practices could be developed toward achieving trustworthiness of AI systems utilized throughout radiological clinical practice workflows from pre-training inputs through validation methodologies to final deployment and ongoing use assessment frameworks. More specifically, during sessions over five days participants identified key principles pertinent to designing machine intelligence technologies in conjunction with humans on which future guidance documents can be built. Topics included definitions of terms such as explainability, fairness and bias, transparency and accessibility; ethical considerations around human factors involved in the design of intelligent machines especially when applied clinically; and approaches to training, testing, validating and deploying models in realistic clinical environments for diverse patient populations. Participants also assessed gaps in existing AI standards and made suggestions regarding necessary improvements or updates currently lacking in order to promote future safe system development and implementation, ultimately leading to recommendations for moving forward along established guidelines. Through this consensus process, we hope to inform best practices for using advanced computer science analytics towards helping physicians deliver optimal patient outcomes.

mistral.title: EdgeFlow: Achieving Practical Interactive Segmentation with Edge-Guided Flow
mistral.prompt: The following is the full text of the abstract for a research paper titled "EdgeFlow: Achieving Practical Interactive Segmentation with Edge-Guided Flow" from arxiv.org:
mistral.generation:
> We present a novel approach to interactive segmentation that is based on a novel edge-guided flow model. Our model is trained on a large dataset of images with segmentation masks, and is able to predict a flow field that can be used to segment new images. The flow field is guided by the edges in the image, which allows the model to capture the structure of the image and produce accurate segmentations. Our model is trained using a novel loss function that is based on the edge-guided flow model. The loss function is designed to encourage the model to produce a flow field that is consistent with the edges in the image. We evaluate our model on a number of benchmark datasets, and show that it is able to produce accurate segmentations. We also show that our model is able to produce segmentations that are more accurate than those produced by other state-of-the-art methods.

The paper is available here.

mistral-chat.title: FUTURE-AI: Guiding Principles and Consensus Recommendations for Trustworthy Artificial Intelligence in Future Medical Imaging
mistral-chat.prompt: Write the abstract for the academic paper titled "FUTURE-AI: Guiding Principles and Consensus Recommendations for Trustworthy Artificial Intelligence in Future Medical Imaging".
mistral-chat.generation: The development of artificial intelligence (AI) has revolutionized various industries, including healthcare. With its potential to improve medical imaging accuracy and speed, AI is increasingly being integrated into clinical workflows for image analysis and interpretation. However, concerns arise about the reliability and trustworthiness of AI systems in this setting. In this paper, we outline guiding principles for building trustworthy AI in future medical imaging using consensus recommendations from a group of experts in the field. Our framework considers multiple dimensions such as data quality, model transparency, human oversight, ethical implications, and patient privacy. We also propose guidelines on how to measure and evaluate AI performance, validate models on new datasets, and incorporate knowledge exchange between humans and machines. These recommendations provide practical insights that can help ensure the responsible use of AI technologies with high stakes, ultimately leading to better outcomes for patients and improving healthcare delivery.

This allows for more accurate and precise segmentation, even in the presence of noise and occlusions. Overall, EdgeFlow represents a significant advancement in the field of interactive segmentation, providing a practical and efficient solution for a wide range of applications.
